header.activity: Friends (ex-colleagues) talking about jobs, learning languages and babies.
header.conv_type: Discussing, explaining, inquiring, advising, requesting, anecdote telling

body.u: thank you so what you know you were telling me about the jobs that you were looking at in the newspaper
mm hm
what kind of jobs they are coming up there?
oh it's a lot of admin sales marketing that kind of thing
for what kind of companies? Did they specify?
no I for in I don't it's not very big town so it's em there's a lot of solicitors yeah but there were quite a few solicitors that were looking for admin but I don't think that's my sort of thing
yeah no definitely I mean if it was an admin in a really interesting exciting company
mm mm
or something it would the you could prob you could probably deal with the the boredom of the admin tasks cos it's an exciting context but then if you're talking about an insurance company
mm
or a firm that makes hangers
no
and what's the pay? Do they advertise the pay in jobs like that?
fifteen sixteen thousand
for full time hours?
mm mm that's not very good it's all like way I think I need to look maybe Express and Mail those kind of papers or on online as well
yeah
did you ever look on Monster Monster Jobs?
monster Jobs? I did in Spain but I haven't looked at it here cos you have to sift through so much
that's what I'm thinking I don't have time with him I I need to find well you know quickly what I want
yeah would you I mean could you set up job alerts? For them to?
mm I did with the NHS I was looking for em speech therapy language assistant
oh really?
but it's really low pay but once you've done that for a couple of years you can do that plus the course at the same time you can become a speech therapist through it
oh wow that's em
it's really hard to do to get in to do it
really?
yeah and I want to find something that's not too far away I found one in Wolverhampton I did apply for that that was last year but I didn't get
mm
shortlisted so
so what you'd start off as an assistant speech therapist?
mm hm
ah
and whilst you're doing that do a course
yeah
and then you can become a speech therapist or there's a one year course but it's in Essex or London
eh huh oh what's wrong?
you'll have it with your relevant degree and then you can do a one year sort of like fast track to be a speech therapist
fantastic
I was interested in it but I'm not sure it's just
yeah
now I've got little
and what do they class as a relevant degree?
well something with lang well languages linguistics em they didn't really list it what what it was but I think linguistics was a main one
what did you study?
linguistics and Spanish
oh really?
yeah
ah that sounds really interesting when you're a speech therapist what em is that working with the NHS?
yeah they that so they they've got their
so yeah tell me about speech therapy is it is it quite em a demanding course?
I think so I mean I read about the modules a bit and it's quite an intense one year course

because you have to learn about everything but and I think you have to specialise I wanted to either do em speech therapy for people who have had brain injuries or children
mm
so but then to do the speech therapy em a assistant you had to have some experience of working with children
oh
before so I didn't have that
oh don't you? Have you not taught kids?
I taught for two weeks one Easter but em I haven't done it more than that no
and doesn't having your own kid?
well now I have
now I have and I'll see how his language develops well I've heard cos he'll be hearing cos he's hearing Polish and English that he'll take l longer to start speaking

yeah I heard that cos I did em psycholinguistics in my degree and wrote wrote a paper about the bilingual lexicon and yeah I heard that that they develop they still develop the two language systems you know like natives?
mm hm
but they do take a little longer
yeah cos you can imagine it's a lot to take in isn't it? It takes long enough when you're learning one language
mm
let alone two em my friend who was from Quebec
mm

in Canada so she spoke like French and I think her mum was eh German so in her house she heard English German and F French and she said she used to say sentences in a mixture of all three languages cos she knew something like cup she only knew it in French so she'd say the whole sentence in English but the French word for cup and she didn't know what it was in in English
I miss speaking Spanglish yeah most of my friends in Spain were em English speakers and Spanish speakers so you could always mix up the two languages in a sentence cos some expressions or some words
mm hm
different languages have better ways of sa expressing it so it's it's weird not using eh Spanglish
my thing was I put English grammar we use the English grammar but with Spanish words sometimes I didn't know and you know you'd be like what?
so when did you learn Spanish?
just doing the degree I think that was my mistake I thought well but Uni offered it as an intensive but it wasn't really that intensive it was like six hours a week
uh-huh
and then you were supposed to finish your degree the same level as someone who's done GCSE plus A level
blimey
so
that's eh that's a lot
and it was then we were we were put together then after the first year with people who had done GCSE A-level plus the first year
crikey
and then intensive
and did you spend time in Spain as part of your degree?
yeah I was in Granada
oh lovely
for nine months and I thought I understood some Spanish but when I went to Granada I didn't understand anyone
mm
except my landlord and he was an English teacher and he spoke really slowly and everything my friend I know how she did it she didn't speak a word she was from Germany
mm hm
and she phoned up places not speaking any Spanish trying to find a place to live how would how you know what do you say to them on the phone? Cos I wouldn't have done it
it is so much more difficult on the phone as well isn't it cos?

yeah we did have when I was when em and luckily I was with eh and she spoke very good Spanish she's Italian she she learnt really quickly and em she would speak to people on the phone and arrange but sometimes they wouldn't want eh non Spanish

there were certain areas that we phoned and they would say no sorry
yeah
we want Spanish speakers
I guess they didn't want people who would be only there for like nine months or something
yeah
mm
and hey
have you been back to Granada's since you lived there?
no I haven't I want to I want to go with and show him where I lived and everything I was really lucky we found a lovely apartment in em

and it was like a the traditional part

it's up by it's not far from The

ah lovely where all the little white houses are

with the patios and aw

oh

but it's lovely
nice
very traditional Spanish

I did yeah I think that's why my Spanish is very em passive knowledge I
mm
I can watch Spanish films I can hear people speak and I can understand but trying to put sentences and express myself
yeah it's difficult isn't it? If you don't practice actually producing it it's it's a lot more difficult to cos you learn a lot of words through li

hearing them don't you?
yeah
but you you don't your brain doesn't actually automatically throw them out until you've actually used them
welI I read Spanish and I say em like I understand that story so I don't understand then why I don't know it when I try and speak it's really weird I and I just really
I think there's some theory that says you have to use a word seven plus or minus two times before your brain can produce it

so you can you can recognise it but you have to actually produc produce it you know a ce a certain amount of times before y you know it's integrated into your vocabulary

mm but the accent as well when I went to Granada it's they say it's like a Brummie accent here people make fun of the the accent from down south in Spain and and when I came back here and spoke with eh boyfriend

is he from the north?

no madrid

eh yes it's similar like
gracia

yeah they don't have the Ss on the end it's like como esta?
but did you practice it a lot or did you like em have a lot of Spanish friends and speak with them or was it a more Erasmus students sticking together?
more Erasmus students not not so much but we were in the faculty of em of translation and interpretation well not you know the translation part
yes
you know translation em part and a lot of the students wanted to practice their English with you

but they said this university was like the equivalent of Oxford and they were you could tell it was it was very good
mm hm
university and their English was very good
mm
with no accents some of the younger students
well they learn it from such a young age over there don't they?

and and you can imagine they like the equivalent of the like rich students they've probably been sent to England every summer and and they they speak English incredibly well so they just used to practice with us with me another English guy there we always used to get people wanting to to talk with us in English and em h he was the same he didn't improve his Spanish he was quite good before but he was there with his family and that was different
mm and did you live with the Italian girl?
I lived with who's from Italy and another girl from Poland
uh-huh so you spoke English at home?
yeah but we we tried sometimes to speak in Spanish

it's really unnatural though isn't it? It's difficult no I was lucky when I went to Spain because I was apart from Lisa who's em bilingual cos her father's Spanish and her mother's English all my friends over there were Spanish so I had to start producing it and
yeah
and I wa I was lucky in that respect is that I became fluent in about six months I knew nothing when I went there
it is I things like having to order and by the end I mean I could do all things like I would things I had to do quite often ordering bombones

things like that or having having to eh I went to the dentist and had to explain in in Spanish what what was wrong and you know and and things like that my Spanish was a lot be my Spanish was a hell of a lot better than when I went I would say
mm
I was a beginner when I went I didn't understand anything
mm but it's the yeah the communication likely you were able to communicate in a shop it's the thing that probably comes first isn't it?
mm
is you're interacting in society were your were your classes in Spanish?
they were they were well and this is the funny thing because it was the translation and I had to take a language so I learned Italian
I ended I ended up giving a presentation in Italian oh giving a presentation in Italian when I was there to learn Spanish
oh no
and I sort of three six nine nine hours a week I did Italian
mm
and it was either Italian French or German I had I had to take that fitted in into my timetable
uh-huh
and I did a translation from Spanish to English science and technology I did translation of newspapers articles and stuff

but I couldn't do it the other way because my Spanish wasn't good enough

so I was just taking it the higher level

modules of transla because for them that was a higher level translation started with English to Spanish

and then Spanish to English so I was in like

mm hm
you're not necessarily translating you're not really developing the skill of translating cos if you learn it through immersion you have kind of a separate system in your head
yeah
so I found it quite difficult to to I don't know sometimes English would just sound when I translated it into English it just didn't sound English and I didn't have that capability of being able to
yeah I had to yeah I had to change it I did one module of theory and of translation and that was quite interesting
mm
but can you imagine like sitting in lectures and I was please don't ask me a question please don't ask me a question

for the first semester I didn't understand any y what the hell they were going on about and I just wanted to not go I thought no no I've got to go I've got to go And I'm glad I did because I think that helped me learn but at first you're just sitting there just listening to them blah blah blah blah blah blah and some of the lecturers are really it's a proper lecturing
mm
there was an older guy we did em Spanish History and em he was just like la la la la la la the whole

yeah he just and he had like his notes in front of him and turn the page la la la la la it was re it was awful and then he'd ask questions at the end and it was like
head down don't pick me
please don't pick me

pardon?

which it all like at university it was very dry
yeah more like studying it as opposed to learning how to use it

yeah and then I but I really enjoyed those classes but all my classmates were Italian except for em well the German girl and I was like sometimes I didn't understand when they spoke Spanish because and the teacher said you know why because they're not speaking Spanish to me they're speaking Italian
and they're just hoping that it's Span
but it is it's so similar I think sometimes it might be more difficult to learn a language that is similar to yours because you know it it comes so naturally to you
mm hm
to say something a certain way as if it's completely different maybe it's easier to remember but no when I I think I went to India about seven years after I'd started living in Spain?

and I hung out with a couple of Italian people and I was surprised that I could understand pretty much everything that they were talking about
yeah
because I spoke Spanish
yeah
and I spoke Spanish to them they understood and they'd speak Italian back to me and and I'd understand
and French helps as well if you've got French and Spanish then you can understand pretty much everything
yeah definitely
Cos there's a lot of crossover between them if it's not similar to Spanish then it's similar to French

mm yeah but no saying that all the Erasmus students the em the ones who did ha get English friends they made fantastic progress but I remember we were living in in the first year with some I think they were Chinese maybe? Em and they just stayed together in their little social groups all the time and

Cos you know

and then it's slowly slid into

as their social life because they didn't really know each other before did they? I think they became more socially em active with each other they started slipping into Chinese more yeah I guess it's typical

I don't know it is hard learning a language it's not an easy thing especially when you when you when you start when you're older I mean I I learnt French at school but I it was a large class of thirty or so students I didn't think I really knew French but I still remember some phrases but I I was definitely not fluent or anything in it

and apart from that I've never studied a language and then I suddenly started Spanish

but because I could put together a sentence quite easily em then people would think oh she speaks Spanish they'd just go brrrrr back so I developed this em defence mechanism of just not letting other people reply just speaking speaking speaking and not giving them a little space to re respond Cos as soon as they'll something and I'll be like I don't know what you've just said sorry
yeah and when you've learnt it you've learnt you say this then they say that then you say this and then they say that and then you say it and they say something completely different and it's like em

oh bless you

oh

and I didn't see it and I was studying Italian at the time and that was really bizarre because I don't I didn't know what to reply I understood what they'd asked me but I wasn't sure how to reply cos I like that's not Spanish but for a second I was a bit frightened that someone has come up to me in Spain and spoke to me not in Spanish but just in Italian and I was a bit confused

I had that when I went to em I went to em I went to Monaco with eh two Spanish friends and an English friend and I was the only one who spoke French and the two Spanish friends didn't speak much English
mm
so we were we were pretty much operating in Spanish apart from me and the English girl we were talking English to each other
mm hm

but everything any kind of interaction with the French world had to come through me so she'd say it to me in English and I had to translate and then the Spanish guys would speak to me in Spanish and I had to translate that into French and there was a moment when just my head and exploding especially because it was culturally as well I was interpreting because em the two guys from eh Murcia they we were at breakfast and they wanted to order toast with tomato on
oh no

I said yeah but look in Fr we're in France you can have croissant you can have pain au chocolat you can have anything sweet and pastry like but toast with tomato on is not part of their culture hello what do you mean? Everyone's got toast surely they've got some tomatoes I was like they don't know how to do it
then again I remember in the first month I think I was in Spain I ordered toast with tomato on and I thought it was gonna come in slices of tomato and when it came with just yeah
like the tomato paste on
yeah cos they just squeeze out the juice and grate a bit of the flesh into it
